content.text: Once upon a time, in a kingdom far away, there lived a prince who was determined to marry a real princess.
Not just any princess—oh no!—but a true princess, one who was gentle, kind, and of the purest royal blood.
The prince traveled the world over, meeting princesses from every land, but none of them seemed quite right. Some were too proud, others too silly, and a few were even a little bit rude.
The prince grew discouraged, for he feared he would never find his true princess. One stormy night, as the wind howled and the rain lashed against the castle windows, there
came a knock at the palace gate. The old king, who was wise and kind, went to see who could possibly be out on such a wild night.
There, standing before him, was a young woman, drenched from head to toe. Her fine clothes clung to her, her hair was tangled with rain, and her shoes were caked with mud.
She shivered and said in a trembling voice, "Please, good sir, I am a princess, and I seek shelter from the storm." The king was doubtful. "A princess?" he thought.
"She looks more like a drowned rat!" But he was too polite to say so. Instead, he welcomed her inside and ordered the servants to prepare a warm bath, dry clothes, and a fine
supper. The queen, who was just as wise as the king, watched the young woman closely. She had a feeling about this stranger—something told her this might be the princess her son
had been searching for. That evening, the prince met the young woman. She was lovely, even with her hair still damp and her cheeks flushed from the cold.
She spoke softly and with great manners, and the prince felt a spark of hope. "Could this be the real princess?" he wondered. But how could they be sure?
The queen, who was clever as well as kind, had an idea. She ordered the servants to prepare the finest guest chamber in the palace.
The bed was made with the softest sheets, the fluffiest pillows, and the warmest blankets. But beneath all these layers, the queen placed a single pea—a tiny, ordinary pea—right in the
middle of the mattress. When the princess was shown to her room, she thanked the queen politely and retired for the night. But as she lay down to sleep, she tossed and turned.
The bed, which should have been the most comfortable in the kingdom, felt lumpy and uneven. She could not get comfortable no matter how she shifted.
The pea beneath the mattresses pressed into her back, keeping her awake all night long. In the morning, the queen asked the princess how she had slept.
The young woman sighed and said, "Oh, Your Majesty, I am so sorry to complain, but I barely slept a wink! There was something hard in the bed, and I am black and blue from it!"
The queen and the king exchanged knowing glances. Only a real princess would be so delicate that she could feel a single pea beneath twenty mattresses and twenty feather beds!
The prince, who had been listening, could hardly contain his joy. He knelt before the princess and said, "Then you are a true princess! No one else could be so sensitive.
Will you marry me?" The princess, who had been just as kind and gentle as she was delicate, smiled and said, "Yes, with all my heart."
And so, the prince and the real princess were married in a grand celebration. The pea was placed in the royal museum, where it can still be seen to this day—if you believe in such
things. And as for the prince and princess? They lived happily, and very comfortably, ever after.
